awd_titl_txt: Two-Dimensional Layered Materials: Thermodynamic and Electrical Studies
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Abstract

With support from the Solid State and Materials Chemistry Program in the Division of Materials Research, this project focuses on the basic scientific research of the properties of small crystals, the education of graduate and undergraduate students, and the further development of specialized scientific instruments such as nanocalorimetry.  Using a newly discovered method, small, two-dimensional crystals of important materials will be grown and the melting temperature and conductive electronic properties will be investigated.  The comprehensive study of these crystals will help develop breakthrough technologies in electronic materials and will provide a new understanding in biological membrane science. Further development of fast-scanning nanocalorimetry will also enhance the national infrastructure of scientific instrumentation. One of the important broader impact goals will be to increase participation in scientific and technical education through the building of devices (e. g. voltmeter and student nanocalorimeter measuring solar and battery heat) within the Native American community.  Blackfeet Community College (BFCC) is located in Browning, Montana, which is the center for the Blackfeet Nation. The activities include a Science Summer Camp at the BFCC for the local students from the middle school, high school and the community college. The research team includes faculty and students from BFCC and the University of Illinois. 

Technical Abstract

The research team will prepare and characterize extremely thin crystals of two-dimensional layered materials (e.g. graphene and chalcogenides).  One key attribute of all two-dimensional layered materials is the very weak van der Waal bonding between layers which allows the stacking of just a few layers.  Special thermodynamic and electronic properties of these materials are only revealed if the crystals are extremely thin - as thin as a single layer of atoms or molecules. The focus of this project is to synthesize and characterize variations of silver alkanethiolates (AgSCn) and chalcogenides using a newly developed vapor deposition technique developed in the principal investigator's laboratory.  The rigid central (Ag-S) plane of the AgSCn crystal controls crystal structure and is the key to its unique electronic properties.  The synthesis activity focuses on incrementally decreasing the number layers of AgSCn (and chalcogenides) down to a single layer and decreasing the chain-length (n) of the alkane side chains down to one-carbon (AgSC1) thiloate.  Using nanocalorimetry, which has the capability of measuring the melting of a single layer of atoms, the principal investigator will measure the melting characteristics of AgSCn crystals. The research team will also study the vertical and lateral conductive properties of the AgSCn and chalcogenides crystals using conductive probe atomic force microscopy.  This dual synthesis and characterization approach will uncover the ultimate structural and electronic properties of these two material systems.  New understanding of these systems is applicable to biological lipid membranes which are another example of single-layer materials, consisting of a single bilayer of organic molecules.

por.por_cntn:
The outcome of our work on 2D membranes for intellectual merit includes several key discoveries.  These findings provide new basic nanoscience understanding of many types of 2D membranes including biological cell membranes and other single layer lamella.  One key outcome includes the discovery of a synthesis method for ultra-short chain lengths of AgSCn membranes, which provides a new route for designing new functional materials with extraordinary properties.  The synthesis was used to generate the ultimate lower size limit of the organometallic layers: AgSC1 and AgSC2.  These membranes have backbones of only one or two carbon molecules with a thickness of only 1 nm. This reserach was published in Dalton Transactions (2016).   At such small sizes another major outcome of the research was the discovery that below a certain membrane thickness ? a critical size exists for bulk-to-discrete transition.  This transition was observed using both thermal analysis including Nanocalorimetry and chemical shift analysis using solid-state NMR.  This finding was published in J. Phys. Chem C (2017).  The key discovery is that crystals of AgSCn below a certain size/thickness have thermodynamic properties, such as the melting point, that are fundamentally and abruptly different than larger crystals.  The implication is that by changing size alone, an entirely new material presents itself.  The melting point changes by as much as 60 degrees C at/below a critical size threshold. Furthermore, this discovery establishes a firm experimental path between ?global? thermal property of the material as measured by calorimetry and the ?local? chemical shift properties as measured by NMR.

The Broad Impact of this research includes outreach activities with the Blackfeet Native Americans, education and promotion of graduate students, and the enhancement of the national infrastructure for instrumentation in science. The PI has partnered with the Blackfeet Community College (BCC) located in Browning, Montana, which is the heart of the Blackfeet Native American Reservation. The Summer Science Camp was organized and implemented with the participation of UIUC graduate & undergraduate students, and included several Native Blackfeet Americans who were administrators and teachers from both the community and local high school.  The camp?s theme was sustainable energy.  The nature of the camp was to promote a hands-on experimental type experience for the students.  The camp consisted of a short course on the soldering of integrated circuits, the assembly of solar kits, and the assembly of Wind Turbines from kits.  All resources are available on our research webpage and the camp was covered in the local newspaper.  The outcome of our effort in the education of graduate students resulted in one student winning two national awards for excellence in research presented at the Materials Research Society (MRS) Graduate Student Award and at NATAS Best Student Award.  The effort to enhance the infrastructure for instrumentation in science was highlighted by a book chapter written with a former graduate student from the PI?s group who is now a leader in metrology expert in the electronic industry.
